elements.Text: However, a post infectious lesion, an emphysema with multiple blebs in the right apex, was noted in August 2019. Follow-up evaluation in April 2020 showed aggravation of the lesion. Eventually, pneumothorax occurred in February 2021. Like this case, accumulation of regular CT scans may be helpful to identify the process of developing pneumothorax of patients with DMD.
Han Eol Cho, MD
Won Ah Choi, MD, PhD
Seong-Woong Kang, MD, PhD
Seoul, Korea

Asian Cardiovasc Thorac Ann. 2013;21(5):582-587.
Robotic Bronchoscopy for Diagnosing Peripheral Lung Lesions
Are We There Yet?
To the Editor:

Improved diagnosis of peripheral lung lesions is of increasing importance because the diagnostic yield of current bronchoscopic approaches remains suboptimal. Therefore, we read with great interest the article in CHEST (February 2021) by Chen et alwho evaluated robotic bronchoscopy in a prospective pilot study.

We congratulate them on the high success rate (96%) of lesion localization by radial endobronchial ultrasound scanning. Can the authors explain how in almost all patients, independent of the presence or absence of a bronchus sign, lesions were detected with radial endobronchial ultrasound scanning? Were patients selected based on chest CT, or were consecutive patients included?

What was the rationale to have “navigational success” as the primary end point? In our opinion, the main determinate of a successful diagnostic procedure is whether representative samples are retrieved; therefore, diagnostic yield would qualify best as the primary end point.
Although we appreciate the rigorous definition of (non-) diagnostic specimens, the discrepancy between lesion detection (96%) and diagnostic yield (74%) is striking. How do the authors explain this?

The findings of Chen et alsupport those of a previous retrospective experience,which suggests that robotic bronchoscopy provides enhanced navigational success but lacks tool-in-lesion confirmation. This is in-line with a cadaver study published in CHEST, in which robotic bronchoscopy demonstrated improved navigation ability over other bronchoscopic techniques but a near-miss rate of the target lesion of 20% remained.

In our opinion, the aforementioned studiesunderline that for adequate bronchoscopic peripheral lung lesion analysis, a two-step approach is desired. First, a bronchoscopic tool is needed to navigate within close proximity of the target lesion. In this respect, the observed 2.3-cm distance between the bronchoscope tip and target lesion by Chen et alis encouraging. Second, a real-time feedback tool, such as cone-beam CT or confocal laser endomicroscopy (CLE), is desirable to confirm the optimal needle positioning. Do the authors support our hypothesis?

In our experience, bronchoscopic CLE imaging through a needle in central and peripheral lung tumors enables realtime malignancy detection at the needle tip,which allows fine-tuning of the optimal needle positioning. Robotic bronchoscopy combined with real-time tool-in-lesion confirmation with the use of needle based CLE imaging is now prospectively evaluated in an ongoing trial ((<http://ClinicalTrials.gov>)ClinicalTrials.gov NCT04441749) and could potentially reduce the current substantial near-miss rate.

Although the results by Chen et allook promising, the discrepancy between navigational success and diagnostic yield requires additional prospective studies to determine best clinical practice and combination of techniques to improve the diagnosis of peripheral lung lesions.
Tess Kramer, MD
Amsterdam, The Netherlands
Christopher J. Manley, MD
Philadelphia, PA
Jouke T. Annema, MD, PhD
Amsterdam, The Netherlands
AFFILIATIONS: From the Department of Respiratory Medicine (T. Kramer and J. T. Annema), Amsterdam UMC, and the Department of Pulmonary and Critical Care (C. Manley), Fox Chase Cancer Center.

FINANCIAL/NONFINANCIAL DISCLOSURES: The authors have reported to CHEST the following: C. M. is a consultant for Auris Health and Johnson and Johnson; J. T. A. received research grants from Mauna Kea Technologies. None declared (T. K.).

Response
To the Editor:

We appreciate the interest that Kramer et al have taken regarding our article on robotic bronchoscopy for peripheral pulmonary lesions (BENEFIT).We will first address their questions regarding specific content within the article before commenting on their proposal for combining robotic bronchoscopy with additional tools and techniques.

Regarding the primary effectiveness end point of lesion localization and the ability to confirm lesion localization with the use of radial endobronchial ultrasound (REBUS) scanning, consecutive patients who met the inclusion criteria were enrolled and underwent robotic bronchoscopy procedures.

The use of navigational success and lesion localization as a primary end point was a calculated selection based on a series of preclinical and clinical studies that we had developed to evaluate robotic bronchoscopy.

This selection was also based on our understanding that a diagnostic biopsy is the result of successful navigation to the targeted lesion, followed by successful biopsy. At the time that these study procedures were performed, there was very little experience with the use of the systems, so this first, prospective multicentered study was designed to evaluate the ability of the robotic systems to locate peripheral lesions and to evaluate the safety profile of the system. A study designed to evaluate diagnostic yield would then be developed with the use of BENEFIT definitions, assuming that lesion localization was successful.

We, and others, previously have published on the discordance between lesion localization and diagnostic yield, so the discrepancy seen in this initial study among novice robotic bronchoscopists is not overly surprising.We have attributed the drop in diagnostic yield to the relative challenges of the successful biopsy of lesions that are adjacent to peripheral bronchi, in which an eccentric radial EBUS image is observed. In prior publications, the diagnostic yield with an eccentric view is 30% to 40%, compared with yields of 80% when a concentric view is obtained.In the BENEFIT trial, the diagnostic yield in the 39% of patients with an eccentric view was 70%, which is higher than the previously reported yields. This, of course is limited by the relatively small number of patients in this study. It is in these patients with adjacent positioning and eccentric radial EBUS views that we feel there is the potential for robotic bronchoscopy to have the greatest impact on diagnostic yield.

Although experience with robotic bronchoscopy is building, the scientific exploration of this technology is still in its early phases. As previously mentioned, BENEFIT was part of a research program in which each study was designed to evaluate a specific and measurable outcome in stepwise progression. Although the results of BENEFIT and prior studies have been encouraging, it remains challenging to have a dialogue about added value in relation to diagnostic yield without a comparison. Given the promise of this emerging technology, we feel strongly that robotic bronchoscopy, and the pulmonary community at large, are deserving of a robust comparative effectiveness trial that would address this.
Finally, Kramer et al propose that based on the results of BENEFIT, additional technology such as cone beam CT or confocal laser
